Topic.Title: Tick-Tock: The Intel Party Doesn't Stop

Message.Msg: The fact is Intel has been blind-sided by ARM's sudden emergence as a viable microprocessor technology alternative.

Topic.Title: Tick-Tock: The Intel Party Doesn't Stop

Message.Msg: I think that it had less to do with ARM than a couple of other tech advances over the last 20 years. Intel was far from alone in missing the impact of these developments. 1. 2G Digital Cellular networks in the early 1990's and mid-1990's network build out helped battery drain and mobile phone size. You didn't have to charge your "brick" every night. 2. iTunes and iPod Touch. 3. iPhone capabilities and customer demand. #1 - 2G phones .... Intel was not interested in becoming a low margin chip supplier. #2 & #3 - iPhone .... was the Apple software and the pricing power that Apple had. I suspect that MIPS had the opportunity at the iPod & iPhone sockets too. I think it had less to do with ARM and more to do with Apple. If Intel was blind sided, it was the same thing that blind sided RIMM, NOK, .... I also think that it had more to do with Steve Jobs and less to do with Apple.

Message.Title: Who has more money, Intel or the "Whole World?"
Message.Msg: I saw a reply from Getanid61 yesterday but didn't have time to respond to it before I left. Now I can't find it. I appreciate people who have differing opinions that can keep the comments on subject. We have a difference of opinion because he feels that ARM has a superior architecture and that people have been investing in ARM to the tune of billions over the past few years. My point is that consumers don't know what's in their phone and probably think there is an Intel processor in their iPhone. So as far as consumers having a legitimate love for ARM I feel it's probably not happening. I said that Intel is vertically integrated which gives it the ability to retain more money. I said the battle comes down to money. He finally asked who has more money, Intel or the rest of the world? Well, geez, if all the countries of the United Nations got together to give money to TSMC, NVidia, TI, and Qualcom then yeah I guess we're outnumbered. But if by the "rest of the world" he means that ARMH, TSMC, UMC, TI, QCOM, nvidia, Samsung, and the other players get together to make one common plan of attack where they can agree about strategy and tactics then yeah Intel is in trouble. But since they each want to maximize their profits, often at the expense of other players in the chain or competition this wont' happen. There is an old American expression "United we stand, divided we fall." Fabless means division, so ta good strong product like Medfield and a strong marketing push like Intel is capable of means that gaining market share won't be that difficult. BTW, the new ARM64 ISA would have been a very welcome thing about 1985. Today Intel is too entrenched in its markets and though some will welcome it most IT pros won't risk their careers on making a bad decision that could cost them a job that would be very difficult to replace.

General Patton's strategy for victory was, "I hit them where they ain't" "Today Intel is too entrenched in its markets and though some will welcome it most IT pros won't risk their careers on making a bad decision that could cost them a job that would be very difficult to replace." They used to say, "No one ever got fired for choosing IBM..." With INtel so entrenched... any chance Microsoft would be porting their OS to ARM... As always... you declare game over before it's begun...

Message.Title: IDF: From the Cloud to Devices, the Future of Innovation is Wide Open
Message.Msg: Intel Developer Forum: From the Cloud to Devices, the Future of Innovation is Wide Open Starts September 11th In its 15th year, the Intel Developer Forum (IDF) remains the place for Intel Corporation, along with high-tech industry developers, executives, designers and engineers, to come together and share their latest innovations and vision for the future of technology. Guided by the theme, “The Future of Innovation is Wide Open,” this year’s event will demonstrate how developers can take advantage of the latest innovations in hardware, software and services to help enable the best user experiences on Intel® architecture -- from the cloud to devices.

Message.Title: Intel: Will They Cut Guidance For The September Quarter?
Message.Msg: Given the ongoing weakness in PC demand, is Intel going to have to cut its Q2 guidance? The chipmaker previously projected 2.2%-9.6% top-line growth. But that’s more optimistic than many other views. Both Dell and HP have downbeat expectations for the quarter, and disk-drive maker Seagate has projected flat sequential growth for the quarter. Citigroup analyst Glen Yeung, while he maintains a Buy rating on Intel shares, cut his target price to $32, from $34. He also trimmed his Q3 EPS forecast to 55 cents a share from 60 cents; for the full year he now sees $2.25 a share, down from $2.36. For 2013, he goes to $2.44 a share, from $2.56. Street consensus is 60 cents for the quarter, $2.39 for this year and $2.55 for next year. “The PC supply chain … continues to deteriorate, driven by a combination of poor macro conditions, tablet cannibalization, and a pause before the Windows 8 launch,” he writes in a research note. “We are cutting estimates on Intel, noting that the potential for pre-announcement is high. Data points from the PC supply chain have been decidedly sub-seasonal. From recent retailer reports (Best Buy, NPD), to OEM reports (Dell, HPQ, Acer) to notebook ODM’s (Wistron, Quanta, Compal), there is little to view positively (except for Lenovo who is gaining share).” He concludes that “the aggregation of data points suggests potential for a negative pre-announcement is high.” INTC is down 6 cents, or 0.2%, to $24.86.

Message.Title: So much for ARM server adoption
Message.Msg: Intel and VMware just rocked to your very foundation. Intel said a recent global survey of about cloud security found that 61 percent of IT professionals are were concerned a lack of control and insight about security capabilities of shared, virtualized datacenter resources. IT pros also have concerns about not having adequate tools to protect against cyber-attacks and 57 percent will not put sensitive data that must meet specific compliance requirements into cloud datacenters, according to Intel. Fifty-five percent or respondents said they worry about loss of control of data stored off premise in public cloud provider datacenters, Intel said. In cloud datacenters, servers are typically virtualized and shared across multiple departments or customers and are no longer dedicated to specific lines of business, creating new security concerns, Intel said.

Topic.Title: Apple seeks ban of 8 Samsung devices

Message.Msg: The point of this article is that Apple is asking for Samsung products to be removed from shelves. Think about it,what happened to coming up with really cool products that people want? When you can't do that any longer you can legislate competition off the shelves! You know, for years we've seen people come on this board and claim that Intel has bribed its way to prosperity and used all kinds of legal tactics to limit competition. But take a good look at Apple. They are outright demanding their best competition be removed from store shelves? And the worst part of all, it gets a pass. Why? Because you love their products or someone you like loves their products? The good news is that Google bought a whole bunch of patents when they bought Motorola and over the next couple of years companies like Blackberry and Nokia may come up for sale, prime picking for Google. Don't forget Kodak. Why? Who uses film anyways? They have many, many, many patents on digital photography. What looks like a legitimate lawsuit is only the first of many lawsuits that will be won back and forth on both sides. Instead of making innovations to improve products companies will have to make work arounds in their designs. This is a losing proposition. It proves nothing!
